title: What are examples of personal attacks fallacies? - Quora

response.answer_text: The most common name for the problem the question addresses is the ad hominem fallacy. It literally means “To the man.” This means, in a debate format, that someone attacks the other debater’s character or motives, rather than the argument’s merits. An example would be “You have no right to oppose abortion. You’re a man and will never be pregnant.” The merits (or lack thereof) of opposition to abortion do not hinge on whether I can or cannot get pregnant. If a woman with a functioning uterus and ovaries argued against abortion, the personal attack would be inapplicable. Other common ad hominem attacks center on someone’s socioeconomic standing or what they stand to gain by supporting or opposing a law or policy. Whether someone personally stands to gain or lose something is immaterial, in most cases, to the argument’s validity and soundness.

A “Personal attack” fallacy is formally called an “ad hominem” fallacy. Typically it refers to a fallacious argumentative strategy whereby genuine discussion of the topic at hand is avoided by instead attacking the character, motive, or other attribute of the person making the argument, or persons associated with the argument, rather than attacking the substance of the argument itself. A simple form is “You cannot believe what person X has just said, because person X (is a bad person, based on some anecdote)” Several examples are provided at: Ad Hominem Examples
